Using LM and AM as before, I also use a small amount of smoothing on the Bleu Score:
 Rather than p = (num)/(length), I do p = (num + (a * length)) / ((1 + a) * length), where a ~= 0.02
 This helps prevent the large deviations (esp. in n = 2, n = 3)
 Overall, scores improve with number of sentences (e.g., n = 3, 0.0375 (1000) -> 0.0466 (10000) -> 0.0479 (15000) -> 0.0489 (30000) )

The different references do differ quite a bit, with Hansard being noticibly better.
 Having more references is better, since there are often more than a few ways to say the same thing. Unfortunately, English can be vague, and it may take a more advanced model \
 or more training data to gaurentee a more accurate translation.
